batch.name: Class 11 - Chapter 7: Structural Organisation in Animals

questions.question: The blood of cockroach is called:
questions.explanation: The blood of cockroach is called haemolymph. It is colourless due to the absence of haemoglobin. It contains colourless plasma and haemocytes (blood cells). It does not transport oxygen.

questions.question: Malpighian tubules in cockroach are organs of:
questions.explanation: Malpighian tubules are the excretory organs of cockroach. They are thin, yellow, filamentous tubules that open into the junction of midgut and hindgut. They help in removal of nitrogenous waste (uric acid).

questions.question: How many pairs of spiracles are present in cockroach?
questions.explanation: Cockroach has 10 pairs of spiracles (2 pairs in the thorax and 8 pairs in the abdomen). These are small openings on the lateral side of the body through which air enters the tracheal system.

questions.question: The body of cockroach is divided into:
questions.explanation: The body of cockroach (Periplaneta americana) is divided into three distinct regions: head, thorax (3 segments), and abdomen (10 segments in both males and females).

questions.question: Mosaic vision is found in cockroach due to:
questions.explanation: Cockroach has compound eyes, each composed of about 2000 ommatidia. Each ommatidium forms a separate image, and the overall image is a mosaic of several images. This type of vision is called mosaic vision and is well adapted for detecting movement.

questions.question: In earthworm, which of the following is the excretory organ?
questions.explanation: In earthworm (Pheretima), nephridia are the excretory organs. There are three types: septal nephridia, integumentary nephridia, and pharyngeal nephridia. They help in osmoregulation and excretion of nitrogenous waste.

questions.question: The gizzard (muscular stomach) in cockroach is part of the:
questions.explanation: The gizzard (proventriculus) is part of the foregut in cockroach. It has an outer layer of thick circular muscles and thick inner cuticle forming six chitinous plates (teeth) for grinding food.

questions.question: The epithelial tissue that lines the blood vessels is:
questions.explanation: Simple squamous epithelium lines the blood vessels (endothelium), body cavities (mesothelium), and air sacs of lungs. These cells are extremely thin and flat, allowing easy diffusion of substances.

questions.question: Clitellum in earthworm is found in segments:
questions.explanation: The clitellum is a prominent band of glandular tissue found in segments 14, 15, and 16 of the earthworm. It secretes a cocoon in which eggs are deposited for fertilization and development.

questions.question: Which type of connective tissue has a fluid matrix?
questions.explanation: Blood is a fluid connective tissue with a liquid matrix called plasma. The cellular components include RBCs, WBCs, and platelets suspended in the plasma.

questions.question: Hepatic caecae (gastric caecae) in cockroach are present at the junction of:
questions.explanation: Hepatic caecae are ring-shaped blind tubules (6-8 in number) present at the junction of foregut and midgut in cockroach. They secrete digestive enzymes and help in digestion.

questions.question: The type of muscle tissue found in the wall of the alimentary canal is:
questions.explanation: Non-striated (smooth) muscle tissue is found in the wall of the alimentary canal, blood vessels, and other visceral organs. It is involuntary, spindle-shaped, uninucleate, and shows slow, sustained contractions.

questions.question: In cockroach, the head is formed by the fusion of how many segments?
questions.explanation: The head of cockroach is formed by the fusion of six segments. It bears a pair of compound eyes, a pair of antennae, and appendages forming the biting and chewing type of mouthparts.

questions.question: Intercalated discs are characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Intercalated discs are specialized cell junctions found between adjacent cardiac muscle cells. They allow rapid conduction of electrical impulses between cells, enabling synchronized contraction of the heart.

questions.question: The number of segments in the thorax of cockroach is:
questions.explanation: The thorax of cockroach has three segments: prothorax, mesothorax, and metathorax. Each segment bears a pair of walking legs. The mesothorax and metathorax each bear a pair of wings.

questions.question: The ciliated epithelium is found in:
options: B) Inner lining of trachea and fallopian tubes
questions.explanation: Ciliated epithelium is found lining the trachea (respiratory tract), bronchi, and fallopian tubes (oviducts). The cilia beat in a coordinated manner to move mucus, particles, or ova along the surface.

questions.question: The mushroom-shaped gland in male cockroach is:
options: A) Phallic gland or conglobate gland
questions.explanation: The mushroom-shaped gland (also called the conglobate gland or phallic gland) is an accessory reproductive gland found in male cockroach. It is present in the 6th-7th abdominal segments.

questions.question: Typhlosole in earthworm is associated with:
options: B) Increasing the absorptive area of the intestine
questions.explanation: Typhlosole is a median fold of the dorsal wall of the intestine in earthworm (from segment 27 onwards). It increases the effective absorptive area of the intestine for efficient digestion and absorption of food.

questions.question: Compound epithelium is found in:
options: B) Dry surface of skin, buccal cavity, pharynx
questions.explanation: Compound epithelium (stratified epithelium) is made of more than one layer of cells. It is found on the dry surface of the skin, in the lining of buccal cavity, pharynx, and inner lining of salivary ducts. It provides protection against chemical and mechanical stresses.

questions.question: Spermathecae (spermatheca) in earthworm are present in segments:
questions.explanation: Earthworm has four pairs of spermathecae located in segments 6-7, 7-8, 8-9, and 9-10 (i.e., they open between these segments). They store spermatozoa received from another earthworm during copulation.

questions.question: The respiratory organ of frog is/are:
options: C) Buccal cavity, skin, and lungs
questions.explanation: Frog respires through three organs: (1) Buccal respiration through the lining of the buccal cavity, (2) Cutaneous respiration through the moist skin (major mode when in water), and (3) Pulmonary respiration through lungs (when on land).

questions.question: The number of abdominal segments in cockroach is:
options: B) 10 in both male and female
C) 10 in male and 8 in female
A) 8 in male and 10 in female
D) 9 in male and 7 in female
questions.explanation: Both male and female cockroach have 10 abdominal segments. However, in females only 7 sternites are visible (7th sternum together with 8th and 9th form a brood pouch), while in males 9 sternites are visible.

questions.question: Which of the following connective tissues connects bones to bones?
questions.explanation: Ligaments are dense connective tissues that connect bones to bones at joints. They are made of yellow elastic fibres and provide elasticity to the joints. Tendons connect muscles to bones.

questions.question: The type of circulatory system in cockroach is:
questions.explanation: Cockroach has an open circulatory system. The blood (haemolymph) flows in open spaces called sinuses (haemocoel) rather than in closed blood vessels. The heart is tubular, 13-chambered, and lies along the mid-dorsal line.

questions.question: In frog, the heart is:
options: D) Three-chambered with partial septum in ventricle
questions.explanation: Frog has a three-chambered heart consisting of two atria (right and left) and one ventricle. The sinus venosus receives deoxygenated blood from the body and opens into the right atrium.

questions.question: Anal cerci are found in:
options: A) Both male and female cockroach
questions.explanation: Anal cerci are a pair of short, thread-like structures found in both male and female cockroach. They are sensory in function. Anal styles are found only in males.

questions.question: Goblet cells are associated with:
options: A) Secretion of mucus in epithelial lining
questions.explanation: Goblet cells are modified columnar epithelial cells that secrete mucus. They are found in the epithelial lining of the alimentary canal (intestine) and the respiratory tract. The mucus lubricates and protects the surface.

questions.question: The testes in cockroach are present in which abdominal segments?
questions.explanation: In male cockroach, testes are a pair of structures lying one on each side of the 4th-6th abdominal segments. Each testis consists of a group of testicular lobes.

questions.question: The cerebral ganglia in cockroach are called the 'brain' and are located in:
questions.explanation: In cockroach, the supra-oesophageal ganglion (brain) is located in the head, above (dorsal to) the oesophagus. It is formed by the fusion of three pairs of ganglia and supplies nerves to the antennae, compound eyes, and labrum.

questions.question: Setae in earthworm help in:
questions.explanation: Setae are S-shaped chitinous structures embedded in the body wall of earthworm. They help in locomotion by anchoring the body to the soil surface. Earthworm has setae arranged segmentally (except the first, last, and clitellar segments).

questions.question: The colleterial glands in female cockroach secrete:
options: B) A protein material for forming the ootheca (egg case)
questions.explanation: Colleterial glands are accessory reproductive glands found in female cockroach. They secrete a thick protein substance that forms the dark reddish-brown egg case called ootheca, which protects the eggs.

questions.question: The Haversian system is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: The Haversian system (osteon) is the functional unit of compact bone. It consists of a central Haversian canal surrounded by concentric lamellae of bone matrix. Osteocytes are present in lacunae between the lamellae.

questions.question: How many pairs of walking legs are present in cockroach?
questions.explanation: Cockroach has three pairs of walking legs, one pair on each thoracic segment (prothorax, mesothorax, and metathorax). Each leg consists of coxa, trochanter, femur, tibia, and tarsus.

questions.question: The nictitating membrane in frog is:
options: A) A transparent eyelid that protects the eye in water
questions.explanation: The nictitating membrane is a transparent, movable lower eyelid that protects the frog's eyes while swimming underwater. It allows the frog to see underwater while protecting the eye.

questions.question: Anal styles in cockroach are found in:
questions.explanation: Anal styles are a pair of short, unjointed structures found only in male cockroach. They are present near the anal cerci and are absent in females. This is an important sexually dimorphic character.

questions.question: In earthworm, blood glands are found in segments:
questions.explanation: Blood glands in earthworm are present in the 4th, 5th, and 6th segments. They produce blood cells (haemocytes) and haemoglobin, which is dissolved in the plasma (not in RBCs).

questions.question: The type of muscle that shows branching and is involuntary is:
questions.explanation: Cardiac muscle fibres are branched, striated, and involuntary. They have intercalated discs between adjacent cells. Unlike skeletal muscles, they contract rhythmically without external stimulation (myogenic).

questions.question: The number of chambers in the heart of cockroach is:
questions.explanation: The heart of cockroach is a tubular, 13-chambered structure lying along the mid-dorsal line beneath the terga. Each chamber has a pair of ostia (valvular openings) for entry of haemolymph.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The blood of cockroach does not carry oxygen.
Reason (R): Cockroach blood (haemolymph) lacks haemoglobin and respiratory pigments; oxygen is transported directly through the tracheal system.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Cockroach haemolymph is colourless and lacks respiratory pigments like haemoglobin. Oxygen is directly delivered to tissues through the tracheal system (network of tubes), so blood does not carry oxygen.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Earthworm is called a friend of farmers.
Reason (R): Earthworm makes burrows in the soil and makes it porous, which helps in aeration and increases soil fertility.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Earthworms are called friends of farmers because their burrowing activity loosens and aerates the soil, their castings enrich the soil with nutrients, and their vermicasts improve soil structure and fertility.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cockroach can detect sound vibrations through its body surface.
Reason (R): Cockroach does not have ears but uses anal cerci as sensors for detecting ground vibrations.
options: D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Cockroach lacks true ears but can sense vibrations through anal cerci and other sensory structures on the body. The anal cerci are appendages that act as sensory receptors for detecting air currents and vibrations.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cardiac muscle shows rhythmic contraction without external stimulation.
Reason (R): Cardiac muscle is myogenic in nature, meaning the impulse for contraction originates from the muscle itself.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Cardiac muscle is myogenic, meaning it generates its own impulse for contraction from the SA node (pacemaker). This allows the heart to beat rhythmically and continuously without requiring nerve signals for each beat.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cockroach is uricotelic.
Reason (R): Cockroach excretes nitrogenous waste in the form of uric acid through Malpighian tubules.
options: D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Cockroach is uricotelic as it excretes uric acid as its primary nitrogenous waste. Malpighian tubules absorb nitrogenous waste from the haemolymph and convert it to uric acid, which is excreted through the hindgut.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Earthworm is hermaphrodite (bisexual).
Reason (R): Despite being bisexual, earthworm requires cross-fertilization due to protandrous condition.
options: C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Earthworm is hermaphrodite (has both male and female reproductive organs) but cannot self-fertilize. It is protandrous (male organs mature before female organs), so cross-fertilization occurs between two individuals.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Frog exhibits sexual dimorphism.
Reason (R): Male frog has vocal sacs and a copulatory (nuptial) pad on the first digit of the forelimb, while females lack these.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Male and female frogs can be distinguished by secondary sexual characters. Males have vocal sacs for croaking and nuptial (copulatory) pads on the first digit of forelimbs for clasping the female during amplexus. Females lack these.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Tendons and ligaments are both dense connective tissues.
Reason (R): Tendons connect muscles to bones and are made of white collagen fibres, while ligaments connect bones to bones and are made of yellow elastic fibres.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. Tendons and ligaments are both dense regular connective tissues. The reason correctly describes their composition and function but does not explain why they are dense connective tissues.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In cockroach, the nervous system is of the ladder type.
Reason (R): The nervous system of cockroach consists of a dorsal nerve cord with segmental ganglia connected by lateral nerves.
options: C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The assertion is true; cockroach has a ladder-like nervous system. However, the reason is false; cockroach has a ventral nerve cord (not dorsal). The paired ventral nerve cord runs along the mid-ventral line with segmental ganglia.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Frog is a poikilothermic (cold-blooded) animal.
Reason (R): The body temperature of frog changes according to the ambient temperature and it cannot regulate its body temperature internally.
options: C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Frog is poikilothermic (ectothermic/cold-blooded), meaning its body temperature varies with the surrounding environment. It lacks an internal thermoregulatory mechanism and hibernates in winter and aestivates in summer.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Ootheca in cockroach contains 14-16 eggs.
Reason (R): Each ootheca is formed by the colleterial glands of the female cockroach.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. The ootheca (egg case) of Periplaneta americana contains 14-16 eggs, and it is formed by secretions from the colleterial glands. However, the gland forming the case does not determine the number of eggs.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about cockroach anatomy:
(i) The body is covered by a hard, brown exoskeleton made of chitin.
(ii) The head is hypognathous (mouthparts directed downward).
(iii) It has two pairs of wings.
(iv) The tegmina (forewings) are used for flight.
How many statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; the tegmina (forewings/mesothoracic wings) are not used for flight. They are dark, opaque, and serve as protective covers. The hind wings (metathoracic) are membranous and are used for flight.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about epithelial tissue is INCORRECT?
(i) Epithelial cells rest on a basement membrane.
(ii) Epithelial tissue has abundant blood supply.
(iii) Epithelial tissue lacks intercellular spaces.
(iv) Epithelial tissue covers body surfaces and lines body cavities.
questions.explanation: Statement (ii) is incorrect. Epithelial tissue is avascular (lacks its own blood supply). It gets nutrients from the underlying connective tissue by diffusion through the basement membrane.

questions.question:
Read the following statements about earthworm:
Statement I: Earthworm breathes through its moist skin.
Statement II: Earthworm has a closed circulatory system.
Statement III: The blood of earthworm contains haemoglobin dissolved in plasma.
Select the correct option:
options: B) I and II are correct
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Earthworm respires through moist skin (cutaneous respiration). It has a closed circulatory system with dorsal and ventral blood vessels. Haemoglobin is dissolved in the plasma, not contained in RBCs.

questions.question:
How many of the following statements about the digestive system of cockroach are correct?
(i) The foregut includes mouth, pharynx, oesophagus, crop, and gizzard.
(ii) Hepatic caecae are at the junction of foregut and midgut.
(iii) Malpighian tubules are at the junction of midgut and hindgut.
(iv) The hindgut includes ileum, colon, and rectum.
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct. The foregut includes mouth, pharynx, oesophagus, crop, and gizzard. Hepatic caecae are at the foregut-midgut junction. Malpighian tubules are at the midgut-hindgut junction. The hindgut has ileum, colon, and rectum.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about connective tissue:
(i) It has cells, fibres, and a matrix.
(ii) Areolar tissue is the most widely distributed connective tissue.
(iii) Adipose tissue stores fat.
(iv) Blood has a fluid matrix called serum.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; the fluid matrix of blood is called plasma (not serum). Serum is plasma from which clotting factors have been removed.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about frog anatomy is INCORRECT?
(i) Frog has a three-chambered heart.
(ii) Frog has no ribs.
(iii) Frog excretes urea (ureotelic).
(iv) Frog has a four-chambered stomach.
questions.explanation: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Frog does not have a four-chambered stomach. It has a simple stomach. Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are all correct. Frog has a 3-chambered heart, no ribs, and is ureotelic.

questions.question:
Select the correct statements about cockroach mouthparts:
(i) Mouthparts are of the biting and chewing type.
(ii) They include labrum, mandibles, first maxillae, second maxillae (labium), and hypopharynx.
(iii) The mandibles are the principal biting organs.
(iv) The mouthparts are appendages of the thorax.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; the mouthparts of cockroach are appendages of the head, not the thorax. They are modified head appendages.

questions.question:
How many of the following are differences between male and female cockroach?
(i) Anal styles present only in males
(ii) Males have 9 visible sternites, females have 7
(iii) Males have colleterial glands
(iv) Females have a brood pouch
(v) Both sexes have anal cerci
questions.explanation: Differences (i), (ii), and (iv) are actual differences between sexes. Statement (iii) is incorrect as colleterial glands are found in females, not males. Statement (v) is a similarity, not a difference.

questions.question:
Consider the following about neural tissue:
(i) Neurons are the structural and functional units.
(ii) Each neuron has a cell body, dendrites, and an axon.
(iii) Neuroglial cells support and protect neurons.
(iv) Neurons can divide throughout life.
Which are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; neurons generally do not divide after maturity. They are mostly post-mitotic cells (exceptions exist in certain brain regions).

questions.question:
Match the epithelial types with their locations:
Column I: (a) Simple squamous (b) Simple cuboidal (c) Simple columnar (d) Ciliated columnar
Column II: (i) Intestinal lining (ii) Blood vessels (iii) Kidney tubules (iv) Trachea and fallopian tubes
questions.explanation: Simple squamous epithelium lines blood vessels. Simple cuboidal epithelium lines kidney tubules. Simple columnar epithelium lines the intestine. Ciliated columnar epithelium lines the trachea and fallopian tubes.

questions.question:
Match the cockroach organs with their functions:
Column I: (a) Malpighian tubules (b) Hepatic caecae (c) Spiracles (d) Gizzard
Column II: (i) Grinding food (ii) Excretion (iii) Secretion of digestive enzymes (iv) Entry of air for respiration
questions.explanation: Malpighian tubules - excretion, Hepatic caecae - secretion of digestive enzymes, Spiracles - entry of air, Gizzard - grinding food. These are key structures in cockroach physiology.

questions.question:
Match the connective tissue types with their matrix:
Column I: (a) Blood (b) Bone (c) Cartilage (d) Areolar tissue
Column II: (i) Hard, calcified (ii) Semi-rigid, chondroitin sulphate (iii) Fluid plasma (iv) Semi-fluid with fibres
questions.explanation: Blood has fluid plasma. Bone has a hard, calcified matrix. Cartilage has a semi-rigid matrix of chondroitin sulphate. Areolar tissue has a semi-fluid matrix with collagen and elastin fibres.

questions.question:
Match the muscle types with their characteristics:
Column I: (a) Skeletal muscle (b) Smooth muscle (c) Cardiac muscle
Column II: (i) Involuntary, non-striated, spindle-shaped (ii) Voluntary, striated, multinucleate (iii) Involuntary, striated, branched with intercalated discs
questions.explanation: Skeletal muscle is voluntary, striated, and multinucleate. Smooth muscle is involuntary, non-striated, and spindle-shaped. Cardiac muscle is involuntary, striated, and branched with intercalated discs.

questions.question:
Match the earthworm structures with their segments:
Column I: (a) Clitellum (b) Male genital pore (c) Female genital pore (d) Spermathecal openings
Column II: (i) 14th segment (ii) 14-16 segments (iii) 18th segment (iv) 5/6, 6/7, 7/8, 8/9 intersegmental grooves
questions.explanation: Clitellum occupies segments 14-16. Male genital pore is on segment 18 (ventral side). Female genital pore is on segment 14. Spermathecal openings are in 5/6, 6/7, 7/8, and 8/9 intersegmental grooves.

questions.question:
Match the excretory organs with the animals:
Column I: (a) Nephridia (b) Malpighian tubules (c) Kidneys (d) Flame cells
Column II: (i) Cockroach (ii) Frog (iii) Earthworm (iv) Flatworms
questions.explanation: Nephridia - Earthworm, Malpighian tubules - Cockroach, Kidneys - Frog, Flame cells - Flatworms (Platyhelminthes).

questions.question:
Match the cockroach body parts with their number:
Column I: (a) Thoracic segments (b) Abdominal segments (c) Pairs of spiracles (d) Chambers of heart
Column II: (i) 10 (ii) 13 (iii) 3 (iv) 10
questions.explanation: Cockroach has 3 thoracic segments, 10 abdominal segments, 10 pairs of spiracles, and a 13-chambered heart.

questions.question:
Match the following glands in cockroach with their function:
Column I: (a) Colleterial glands (b) Phallic/Mushroom gland (c) Salivary glands (d) Hepatic caecae
Column II: (i) Digestion of food (ii) Male accessory gland (iii) Formation of ootheca (iv) Secretion of saliva
questions.explanation: Colleterial glands form ootheca (egg case). Phallic/Mushroom gland is a male accessory reproductive gland. Salivary glands secrete saliva. Hepatic caecae secrete digestive enzymes.

questions.question:
Match the following animal tissues with their features:
Column I: (a) Areolar tissue (b) Adipose tissue (c) Dense regular tissue (d) Cartilage
Column II: (i) Fat-filled cells (ii) Present in tendons/ligaments (iii) Found between skin and muscles (iv) Chondrocytes in lacunae
questions.explanation: Areolar tissue is found between skin and muscles (filling spaces). Adipose tissue has fat-filled cells. Dense regular tissue is found in tendons and ligaments. Cartilage has chondrocytes in lacunae.

questions.question:
Match the type of nephridia in earthworm with their location:
Column I: (a) Septal nephridia (b) Integumentary nephridia (c) Pharyngeal nephridia
Column II: (i) Attached to body wall (ii) Present on both sides of the septa (iii) Present as tufts in 4th, 5th, 6th segments
questions.explanation: Septal nephridia are present on both sides of the intersegmental septa (from segment 15 onwards). Integumentary nephridia are attached to the body wall. Pharyngeal nephridia are found as tufts in the 4th, 5th, and 6th segments.

questions.question: How many pairs of walking legs does a cockroach have?
questions.explanation: Cockroach has 3 pairs of walking legs (one pair per thoracic segment). The first pair is from prothorax, second from mesothorax, and third from metathorax.

questions.question:
How many of the following are types of animal tissues?
(i) Epithelial tissue (ii) Connective tissue (iii) Muscular tissue (iv) Neural tissue (v) Meristematic tissue
questions.explanation: There are four types of animal tissues: epithelial, connective, muscular, and neural. Meristematic tissue is a plant tissue, not an animal tissue.

questions.question: How many segments fuse to form the head of cockroach?
questions.explanation: The head of cockroach is formed by the fusion of six segments. It is triangular in shape and lies at right angles to the long axis of the body.

questions.question: How many types of nephridia are found in earthworm?
questions.explanation: Earthworm has three types of nephridia: (1) Septal nephridia (on septa from segment 15), (2) Integumentary nephridia (on body wall from segment 3), and (3) Pharyngeal nephridia (in segments 4, 5, 6).

questions.question: How many ommatidia are approximately present in each compound eye of cockroach?
questions.explanation: Each compound eye of cockroach has about 2000 ommatidia. Each ommatidium is a visual unit that produces a portion of the overall mosaic image perceived by the cockroach.

questions.question: How many eggs are present in each ootheca of cockroach?
questions.explanation: Each ootheca (egg case) of Periplaneta americana contains 14-16 eggs arranged in two rows. The female drops the ootheca after its formation. The nymphs hatch after about 6 weeks.

questions.question: How many visible sternites are present in male cockroach?
questions.explanation: In male cockroach, 9 sternites are visible on the ventral side. In females, only 7 sternites are visible because the 7th sternum together with 8th and 9th forms a brood or genital pouch.

questions.question: Arrange the parts of the cockroach alimentary canal in correct order from mouth to anus:
options: B) Mouth  Oesophagus  Pharynx  Gizzard  Crop  Midgut  Hindgut  Anus
A) Mouth  Pharynx  Oesophagus  Crop  Gizzard  Midgut  Hindgut  Anus
C) Mouth  Pharynx  Crop  Oesophagus  Gizzard  Midgut  Hindgut  Anus
D) Mouth  Pharynx  Oesophagus  Gizzard  Crop  Midgut  Hindgut  Anus
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Mouth  Pharynx  Oesophagus  Crop (food storage)  Gizzard/Proventriculus (grinding)  Midgut/Mesenteron (digestion and absorption)  Hindgut/Proctodaeum (ileum, colon, rectum)  Anus.

questions.question: Arrange the levels of structural organisation in animals from simplest to most complex:
options: D) Organ systems  Organs  Tissues  Cells  Organism
C) Cells  Organs  Tissues  Organ systems  Organism
B) Tissues  Cells  Organs  Organ systems  Organism
A) Cells  Tissues  Organs  Organ systems  Organism
questions.explanation: The hierarchy of structural organisation from simplest to most complex is: Cells  Tissues (groups of similar cells)  Organs (groups of tissues)  Organ systems (groups of organs)  Organism.

questions.question: Arrange the segments of a cockroach leg from proximal (body) to distal (tip):
options: D) Trochanter  Coxa  Femur  Tarsus  Tibia
B) Tarsus  Tibia  Femur  Trochanter  Coxa
A) Coxa  Trochanter  Femur  Tibia  Tarsus
C) Coxa  Femur  Trochanter  Tibia  Tarsus
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of leg segments from proximal to distal is: Coxa (attached to body)  Trochanter  Femur  Tibia  Tarsus (most distal, with claws/pulvilli for climbing).

questions.question: Arrange the following structures in the cockroach nervous system from anterior to posterior:
options: B) Sub-oesophageal ganglion  Supra-oesophageal ganglion  Abdominal ganglia  Thoracic ganglia
A) Supra-oesophageal ganglion  Sub-oesophageal ganglion  Thoracic ganglia  Abdominal ganglia
C) Thoracic ganglia  Supra-oesophageal ganglion  Sub-oesophageal ganglion  Abdominal ganglia
D) Abdominal ganglia  Thoracic ganglia  Sub-oesophageal ganglion  Supra-oesophageal ganglion
questions.explanation: From anterior to posterior: Supra-oesophageal ganglion (brain, in head)  Sub-oesophageal ganglion (below oesophagus, in head)  Three thoracic ganglia  Six abdominal ganglia. They are connected by the paired ventral nerve cord.

questions.question: Arrange the cockroach mouthparts from outermost to innermost:
options: A) Labrum  Mandibles  First maxillae  Labium (Second maxillae)  Hypopharynx
B) Mandibles  Labrum  First maxillae  Hypopharynx  Labium
C) Labium  First maxillae  Mandibles  Labrum  Hypopharynx
D) Hypopharynx  Labrum  Mandibles  First maxillae  Labium
questions.explanation: From outermost to innermost: Labrum (upper lip)  Mandibles (main biting organs)  First maxillae (accessory feeding)  Labium/Second maxillae (lower lip)  Hypopharynx (tongue-like, innermost).

questions.question: Arrange the following events in cockroach development in correct order:
options: A) Egg in ootheca  Nymph  Several moults  Adult
questions.explanation: Cockroach shows incomplete metamorphosis (hemimetabolous). The sequence is: Eggs in ootheca  Nymphs hatch  Several moults (about 13 moulting stages)  Adult. There is no pupal stage (no complete metamorphosis).

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the body wall of earthworm from outermost to innermost:
options: C) Muscle layers  Cuticle  Epidermis  Coelomic epithelium
A) Cuticle  Epidermis  Muscle layers  Coelomic epithelium
B) Epidermis  Cuticle  Coelomic epithelium  Muscle layers
D) Coelomic epithelium  Muscle layers  Epidermis  Cuticle
questions.explanation: From outermost to innermost: Cuticle (thin non-cellular)  Epidermis (single-layered columnar cells)  Muscle layers (outer circular, inner longitudinal)  Coelomic epithelium (innermost lining of the coelom).

questions.question: The hepatic portal system in frog carries blood from:
questions.explanation: The hepatic portal system in frog carries nutrient-rich blood from the intestine (alimentary canal) to the liver via the hepatic portal vein. This allows the liver to process nutrients before they enter general circulation.

questions.question: Transitional epithelium is found in:
questions.explanation: Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is a type of stratified epithelium found lining the urinary bladder, ureters, and renal pelvis. It can stretch to accommodate changes in volume of the organ.

questions.question: The fat body in cockroach serves as:
options: B) Storage of fat, glycogen, and excretory products
questions.explanation: The fat body in cockroach is a loose tissue found beneath the terga in the haemocoel. It stores fat and glycogen and also acts as a storage organ for uric acid (excretory product).

questions.question: In frog, the tympanic membrane is associated with:
questions.explanation: The tympanic membrane (tympanum/eardrum) in frog is a circular disc-like membrane that receives sound vibrations and transmits them to the inner ear through the columella (stapes). It is located behind each eye.

questions.question: Chondrocytes are found in:
questions.explanation: Chondrocytes are the cells of cartilage. They are enclosed in small spaces called lacunae within the matrix of chondroitin sulphate. Cartilage is semi-rigid and provides support and flexibility.

questions.question: The proventriculus (gizzard) in cockroach has thick cuticle forming:
questions.explanation: The proventriculus (gizzard) of cockroach has a thick inner cuticle forming 6 highly chitinous plates called teeth. These are used for grinding the food into fine particles.

questions.question: Areolar tissue is found:
options: B) Between skin and muscles, around blood vessels and nerves
questions.explanation: Areolar tissue is the most widely distributed connective tissue. It is found between the skin and muscles, around blood vessels, nerves, and organs. It contains fibroblasts, mast cells, macrophages, and collagen and elastin fibres.

questions.question: In earthworm, the blood vascular system is:
questions.explanation: Earthworm has a closed circulatory system, meaning blood flows in closed blood vessels. It has a dorsal blood vessel (carrying blood anteriorly), ventral vessel (carrying blood posteriorly), and 4 pairs of 'hearts' (lateral hearts in segments 7, 9, 12, 13).

questions.question: Which structure in cockroach stores food temporarily?
questions.explanation: The crop is a thin-walled, sac-like structure in the foregut of cockroach that temporarily stores food. The food is then passed to the gizzard for grinding.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Bone is the hardest connective tissue.
Reason (R): Bone matrix is impregnated with calcium salts (calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate) and collagen fibres.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Bone is the hardest connective tissue. Its hardness is due to the deposition of calcium salts (mainly calcium phosphate) in the ground substance along with collagen fibres, which makes the matrix rigid and strong.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cockroach shows incomplete metamorphosis.
Reason (R): The development of cockroach passes through nymphal stages and there is no pupal stage.
options: C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Cockroach shows incomplete metamorphosis (hemimetabolous development). Nymphs resemble adults but are smaller and wingless. There is no larval or pupal stage, unlike complete metamorphosis seen in butterflies.

questions.question:
How many of the following statements about cartilage are correct?
(i) Cartilage has a solid but pliable matrix.
(ii) Chondrocytes are enclosed in lacunae.
(iii) Cartilage has abundant blood supply.
(iv) Cartilage is found in the nose tip, ear pinna, and tracheal rings.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (iii) is incorrect because cartilage is avascular (lacks blood supply); it receives nutrients by diffusion. This is why cartilage injuries heal slowly.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the tracheal system of cockroach is correct?
(i) Air enters through spiracles.
(ii) The tracheal tubes branch into tracheoles.
(iii) Tracheoles carry oxygen directly to the tissues.
(iv) Blood carries oxygen from tracheae to tissues.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect because in cockroach, the tracheal system directly delivers oxygen to the tissues through tracheoles. Blood (haemolymph) does not carry oxygen.

questions.question:
Match the frog organ systems with their features:
Column I: (a) Circulatory system (b) Respiratory system (c) Excretory system (d) Nervous system
Column II: (i) Mesonephric kidneys, ureotelic (ii) 3-chambered heart (iii) 10 pairs of cranial nerves (iv) Cutaneous, pulmonary, buccal
questions.explanation: Frog has a 3-chambered heart (circulatory), respires through skin, lungs, and buccal cavity (respiratory), has mesonephric kidneys and is ureotelic (excretory), and has 10 pairs of cranial nerves (nervous).

questions.question:
Match the following types of glandular epithelium:
Column I: (a) Unicellular gland (b) Multicellular exocrine (c) Endocrine gland
Column II: (i) Secrete hormones into blood (ii) Goblet cells (iii) Salivary glands
questions.explanation: Goblet cells are unicellular glands. Salivary glands are multicellular exocrine glands (secrete via ducts). Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into blood (ductless).

questions.question: How many pairs of spermathecae are present in earthworm?
questions.explanation: Earthworm has four pairs of spermathecae, located in segments 6-7, 7-8, 8-9, and 9-10. They receive and store spermatozoa from the partner during copulation.

questions.question:
Arrange the path of air in the cockroach respiratory system from entry to tissue:
(i) Spiracles (ii) Tracheal trunks (iii) Tracheoles (iv) Body tissues
questions.explanation: Air enters through spiracles  passes through tracheal trunks (main branches)  divides into smaller tracheoles  oxygen diffuses directly into the body tissues. This is a highly efficient system for direct gas delivery.

questions.question: The type of coelom present in earthworm is:
questions.explanation: Earthworm is a true coelomate. The coelom is a body cavity lined by mesoderm on both sides (schizocoelous type). The coelomic fluid serves in locomotion and provides a hydrostatic skeleton.
